Text_Numeracy: As a bank teller, I was standing in my teller line, when an elderly gentleman who I recognized as a long-time customer approached my window. He appeared to be wobbly on his feet; when I asked him how he was doing is response was, "Ok, but I'm a little dizzy." I looked closely at him, and noticed that he looked pale, sweaty and somewhat disoriented. I told him that I was afraid that he might be getting orthostatic hypotension, and that I wanted him to sit down for a few minutes to let the sensation pass. He sat down, but did not feel much better. I offered him a glass of water and a piece of sweet candy that we keep on our customer services desk for the kids. He declined the water but accepted the candy. Two minutes later he was much better and said he felt that he might be able to start going again. I asked him to wait two more minutes until his body was able to achieve a better standing position without fainting. He stood up 5 minutes after he started sitting, and walked off to continue his banking business somewhat irritated with me for making him sit. I was able to discern his symptoms based on previous readings of medical literature and various media outlets (hospital brochures).

Text_Numeracy: In high school, I volunteered at a nursing home, thereby receiving training on various medical equipment. One day, I observed the nurse prepping a patient for dialysis. Knowing that blood pressure and fluid intake were two important considerations when it came to dialysis treatment, I asked the nurse how the patient’s VS were. She said that they were fine so she was pumping the patient with fluids. I asked how much was too much and was given a blank stare. Then, she asked me if I knew what a fluid overload was. When I said yes, she then explained that she wouldn’t pump them with too much fluid. 10 mins before treatment, she checked the vitals and BP was sky high. The nurse ran for meds to lower BP; treatment was delayed; patient complained of pain during treatment; and even after treatment was complete patient’s BP was very low (much lower than baseline). Patient almost coded. I wasn’t there for the aftermath, but let’s just say I never made that nurse again.

Text_Anxiety: Stepping into a doctor's office can be like walking into an episode of a soap opera - filled with suspense and unexpected twists. For me, the anxiety kicks in when I wonder if they'll find something I didn't. What if it turns out I have a severe fish allergy? Or orthopedic evil twin syndrome? In any case, it feels a bit like a gamble, and who wants to lose at gambling?
Text_TrustPhys: My primary care physician is a trustworthy thorough and considerate doctor that I have known for many years and is familiar with my background.  I have complete confidence in his ability to provide I need,  and I very rarely ever need to go.  Probably because I am a pretty healthy 51 year old female.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I feel slightly above average in my ability to obtain and understand basic health information. The only reason I don't feel fully confident is occasionly experiencing difficulty in the time I have available to get all of the information I need or have questions about

Text_Numeracy: Once I gave my dad medicine for high blood pressure to quickly decrease it before we reached the doctor my dad has high blood pressure and I feel great helping get it down before we reached the doctor
Text_Anxiety: The idea of visiting a doctor who may not speak the same language as me is unsettling. I have to have a translator.
Text_TrustPhys: I have a low level of trust in doctors, especially in primary care doctors because they are rushed and have high patient loads. One doctor covers many patients and has many health and life issues to deal with.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I strongly feel that I have the capacity to obtain, process and understand the necessary health information and services needed to make the appropriate health decisions related to my health

Text_Numeracy: When my son was about 2 years old, he woke up one night crying that his tummy hurt. I took his temp and it was 101.5. I took him to the ER, and it turned out he had appendicitis.
Text_Anxiety: That I'll have something serious or life-threatening, and that treatment will be difficult or not effect and I won't have much time left.
Text_TrustPhys: Doctor often seems in a hurry to get me out.  Mostly concerned about basic stuff to do a well check.  Always has a reason I need to come back but it's to do things that don't really matter to me
Text_SubjectiveLit: I believe that I have a high capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information and services. I am on the internet fairly often and I Google questions when I have them. Additionally, if I really have a question about something, I will always ask a doctor when I am seeing them.

Text_Numeracy: I once helped a friend who was experiencing symptoms of heat exhaustion during a hiking trip. I recognized the signs - dizziness, nausea, and rapid pulse - and quickly took action by getting them to a shaded area, giving them water, and removing excess clothing. I knew the importance of hydration and cooling down the body to prevent further complications. My quick thinking and knowledge of health issues helped ensure my friend received the necessary care before seeking professional medical help.
Text_Anxiety: I feel most anxious when visiting the doctor's office when I have to discuss any potential health concerns or receive news about test results. I tend to worry about the unknown and the possibility of facing health issues that may impact my active lifestyle. Additionally, the fear of being prescribed medication or undergoing treatments that could disrupt my routine also adds to my anxiety during doctor visits.
Text_TrustPhys: I trust my primary care physician because they have consistently provided me with thorough and personalized care, taking the time to listen to my concerns and involve me in decision-making about my health. They have earned my trust through their expertise, empathy, and responsiveness to my needs. Additionally, their approach to treatment aligns with my preferences for holistic and preventative care, which further solidifies my confidence in their medical advice.
Text_SubjectiveLit: Well, I consider myself to have a strong capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information and services. I actively engage in physical activities weekly, which I believe contributes to my overall well-being. While I don't take many prescription drugs regularly, I do visit my primary care physician occasionally to ensure I am taking care of my health proactively. I believe in a holistic approach to health, which includes staying active, eating well, and seeking medical advice when needed.
